title: Quercus lamellosa
text:
Quercus lamellosa (syn. "Cyclobalanopsis lamellosa") is a species of <a href="Quercus">oak</a> native to the <a href="Himalaya">Himalaya</a> and adjoining mountains from <a href="Tibet">Tibet</a> and <a href="Nepal">Nepal</a> east as far as <a href="Guangxi">Guangxi</a> and northern <a href="Thailand">Thailand</a>, growing at altitudes of 1300–2500 m. The <a href="Lepcha%20people">Lepcha</a> of <a href="Sikkim">Sikkim</a> call it .
"Quercus lamellosa" is a medium-sized to large <a href="evergreen">evergreen</a> <a href="tree">tree</a> growing to 40 m tall with a trunk up to 1.5 m diameter. The <a href="leaf">leaves</a> are spirally arranged, ovate-elliptic, 16–45 cm long and 6–15 cm broad, with a sharply serrated margin. The <a href="flower">flower</a>s are <a href="catkin">catkin</a>s, the female flowers maturing into broad <a href="acorn">acorn</a>s 2–3 cm long and 3–4 cm broad, set in a deep <a href="Calybium%20and%20cupule">cupule</a> with concentric rings of woody scales.
<a href="Joseph%20Dalton%20Hooker">Joseph Dalton Hooker</a> commented,
"Quercus lamellosa" is occasionally cultivated as an <a href="ornamental%20tree">ornamental tree</a> in warm-temperate climates; in the <a href="British%20Isles">British Isles</a>, cultivation is only successful in the milder parts of <a href="Ireland">Ireland</a> and <a href="Cornwall">Cornwall</a>.
